<!-- Proposed additions to the list should be discussed on the Talk page. Archived links can be found on the Talk page as well. New additions need to be properly referenced following the existing format and placed in proper, ascending chronological order. -->
+
<!-- ATTENTION: PLEASE ONLY ADD MEDIA-COVERED REFERENCES TO THIS SECTION. Per the consensus reached on this article's talk page, non-media-covered references (such as an occurrence in a video game) should be placed in the article List of cultural references to "All your base are belong to us" -->
Due to its immense popularity, the phrase or some variation of the lines from the game has been seen in innumerable articles, books, comics, clothing, movies, radio shows, songs, television shows, video games, webcomics, and websites. However, few have actually drawn any legitimate media attention. A selection of those that have garnered such coverage follows; a [[Google]] search will turn up thousands more hits on individual websites.

However, few have actually drawn any legitimate media attention. Line 27: Line 27:
*On [[2001-02-23]], [[Wired (magazine)|''Wired'']] provided an early report on the phenomenon in an article entitled âWhen Gamer Humor Attacks,â which covered everything from the Flash animation to its spread through [[e-mail]] and Internet forums to [[T-shirt]]s bearing the phrase.<ref>{{cite web | author=Benner, Jeffrey | date=[[2001-02-23]] | url=http://www.wired.com/news/culture/0,1284,42009,00.html | title=When Gamer Humor Attacks | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
*On [[2001-02-23]], [[Wired (magazine)|''Wired'']] provided an early report on the phenomenon in an article entitled âWhen Gamer Humor Attacks,â which covered everything from the Flash animation to its spread through [[e-mail]] and Internet forums to [[T-shirt]]s bearing the phrase.<ref>{{cite web | author=Benner, Jeffrey | date=[[2001-02-23]] | url=http://www.wired.com/news/culture/0,1284,42009,00.html | title=When Gamer Humor Attacks | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>

Thanks for your cooperation. -->Warquest.''<ref>{{cite web | author=Amend, Bill | date=[[2001-03-12]] | url=http://homepage.mac.com/brossow/wikipedia/foxtrot_aybabtu.gif | title=FoxTrot | format=GIF | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
*In the ''[[FoxTrot]]'' [[comic strip]] on [[2001-03-12]], Jason Fox (the [[nerd]]y youngest child) began to shout, âAll your base are belong to us!â confusing his parents. [[Bill Amend]] has been known to incorporate âgeek cultureâ into his comic strips, such as the fictional [[MMORPG]] ''World of <!-- READ THIS: Please DO NOT CHANGE THIS to âWarcraftâââWarcraftâ is a fictional game from the comic strip, obviously a joke mixing Warcraft and Everquest. Thanks for your cooperation. -->Warquest.''<ref>{{cite web | author=Amend, Bill | date=[[2001-03-12]] | url=http://homepage.mac.com/brossow/wikipedia/foxtrot_aybabtu.gif | title=FoxTrot | format=GIF | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
â
*In the game ''[[Rome: Total War]]'', an Egyptian diplomat states "Pharoah says "All Your Base Are Belong To Us" when demanding protectorate status.
  â
*In the game ''[[Warcraft III|Warcraft III: Reign of Chaos]]'' and its expansion pack, ''[[Warcraft III: The Frozen Throne]]'', the cheat code âAll Your Base Are Belong To Usâ leads to automatic victory and âSomebody Set Up Us The Bombâ leads to automatic defeat.
  â
*In the game ''[[Empire Earth]]'', if you type in the cheat "All your base are belong to us," all of your resources increase by 100,000.
  â
*In ''[[Civilization III]]'', a defeated player is mocked and jeered by the leaders of his opposing civilizations, and one of the random taunts is "All Your Base Are Belong To Us!"
  â
*In the game ''[[Guild Wars]]'', the warrior class features a shout entitled "For Great Justice!"
 
*On [[2002-01-06]], an episode of the television show ''[[Futurama]]'' (â[[Anthology of Interest II]],â episode #403) featured a segment in which a robot named Beserk said, "All your base are belong to us."<ref>{{cite web | author=Morton, Lewis | date=[[2002-01-06]] | url=http://www.imsdb.com/transcripts/Futurama-Anthology-Of-Interest-II.html | title=âAnthology Of Interest IIâ Transcript at IMSDb | work=Internet Movie Script Database | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
*On [[2002-01-06]], an episode of the television show ''[[Futurama]]'' (â[[Anthology of Interest II]],â episode #403) featured a segment in which a robot named Beserk said, "All your base are belong to us."<ref>{{cite web | author=Morton, Lewis | date=[[2002-01-06]] | url=http://www.imsdb.com/transcripts/Futurama-Anthology-Of-Interest-II.html | title=âAnthology Of Interest IIâ Transcript at IMSDb | work=Internet Movie Script Database | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
*On [[2003-04-01]], in [[Sturgis, Michigan]], seven men aged 17 to 20 placed signs all over town that read, "All your base are belong to us. You have no chance to survive make your time." They said they were playing an [[April Fool's Day|April Fool's]] joke by mimicking the famous Flash animation that ubiquitously depicted the slogan. Not many people who saw the signs were familiar with the joke, however. Many residents were upset that the signs appeared while the U.S. was at [[2003 invasion of Iraq|war with Iraq]], and police chief Eugene Alli said the signs could be âa borderline terrorist threat depending on what someone interprets it to mean.â<ref>{{cite web | author=Doyle, Holly | date=[[2003-04-04]] | url=http://wwmt.com/engine.pl?station=wwmt&id=468&template=breakout_local.html | title=Men arrested for âAll Your Baseâ prank | work=WWMT â Digital Channel 3 | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
*On [[2003-04-01]], in [[Sturgis, Michigan]], seven men aged 17 to 20 placed signs all over town that read, "All your base are belong to us. You have no chance to survive make your time." They said they were playing an [[April Fool's Day|April Fool's]] joke by mimicking the famous Flash animation that ubiquitously depicted the slogan. Not many people who saw the signs were familiar with the joke, however. Many residents were upset that the signs appeared while the U.S. was at [[2003 invasion of Iraq|war with Iraq]], and police chief Eugene Alli said the signs could be âa borderline terrorist threat depending on what someone interprets it to mean.â<ref>{{cite web | author=Doyle, Holly | date=[[2003-04-04]] | url=http://wwmt.com/engine.pl?station=wwmt&id=468&template=breakout_local.html | title=Men arrested for âAll Your Baseâ prank | work=WWMT â Digital Channel 3 | accessdate=2006-05-15}}</ref>
